title: What Does W/ Mean over Text or Online?

steps.content: â€œW/â€ is shorthand for â€œwithâ€ online or on paper. Even though â€œwithâ€ is already a short word, â€œW/â€ is still faster to write by hand and uses fewer characters when itâ€™s typed out. It can be capitalized or lowercase (â€œw/â€), and can appear without a slash (â€œwâ€) or with a period instead (â€œw.â€). [1] X Research source â€œW/â€ shows up in informal writing like text messages, social media, handwritten notes or instructions, recipes, apartment listings, or even casual Slack messages and emails at work. [2] X Research source â€œFor rent: Renovated 1-bed apartment w/ great view of downtownâ€ â€œChop 1 potato w/ skin onâ€ â€œLetâ€™s ride w David since heâ€™s leaving earlier.â€ â€œIâ€™m on my way to the store w. Karenâ€

steps.title: â€œWâ€ (without a slash) can mean â€œwinâ€ or â€œwinningâ€ over text or online.
steps.content: â€œWâ€ (without a slash) can mean â€œwinâ€ or â€œwinningâ€ over text or online. If you see a plain â€œWâ€ by itself or as part of a celebratory sentence in a text or on an app like TikTok or Twitter, chances are the user means â€œwinâ€ or â€œwinning.â€ [3] X Research source This meaning comes up almost exclusively online (although you might hear someone say something like â€œWe got the â€˜dub!â€ out loud, where â€œâ€˜dubâ€ is a shortening of â€œdouble-uâ€). Similarly, you might see â€œLâ€ as shorthand for â€œlossâ€ or â€œlosing.â€ [4] X Research source â€œI got a promotion today! ğŸ‰ Can I get a W in the group chat!?â€ â€œCubs get the W!â€ Person A: â€œI got my driverâ€™s license!â€ Person B: â€œW!â€

steps.title: Type or write â€œW/â€ in place of â€œwithâ€ in informal communications.
steps.content: Type or write â€œW/â€ in place of â€œwithâ€ in informal communications. Use â€œW/â€ any time youâ€™d use â€œwithâ€ in a sentence (itâ€™s that flexible!). Type it when youâ€™re posting on social media, texting, writing quick notes during class or a meeting, or leaving instructions for your dog sitter. Only abbreviate â€œwithâ€ in casual messages, thoughâ€”itâ€™s best to avoid it in formal or professional writing and use the full word â€œwith.â€ [5] X Research source â€œLetâ€™s go on a walk w/ Richard today!â€ â€œGive my puppy her vitamin w/ dinner when you watch herâ€

steps.title: Use â€œW/Oâ€ to mean â€œwithout.â€
steps.content: Use â€œW/Oâ€ to mean â€œwithout.â€ Add an â€œOâ€ after the slash in â€œW/â€ to form the abbreviation for â€œwithoutâ€ and use â€œw/oâ€ the same way youâ€™d use â€œw/.â€ Throw it in casual texts or messages, tweets or other social media posts, notes, instructions, or any other scenario where you need to save some space or characters. [6] X Research source â€œAre you ordering food? Get me a hotdog w/o ketchup please!â€ â€œHurry up or weâ€™re leaving w/o you!â€

steps.title: Throw a â€œWâ€ in the chat to celebrate a win over text or online.
steps.content: Throw a â€œWâ€ in the chat to celebrate a win over text or online. Reply to someoneâ€™s text with â€œWâ€ or leave a â€œWâ€ comment on a tweet or TikTok video to congratulate others. Post â€œWâ€ by itself to use it as an exclamation (â€œWinning!â€) or use it as part of a full sentence (â€œThe Bears take the W!â€). Try using some emojis to keep things fun and celebratory! [7] X Research source â€œNice job at your track meet today. Congrats on your W!â€ Them: â€œHereâ€™s a pic of my outfit for the awards show!â€ You: â€œW!â€

steps.title: â€œW/â€ probably came from handwritten fast food orders in the 1950s.
steps.content: â€œW/â€ probably came from handwritten fast food orders in the 1950s. As speed became more important for restaurant workers, servers began using shorthand to take orders by hand. â€œW/â€ and â€œW/Oâ€ were quick and easy to understand ways to say â€œwithâ€ and â€œwithoutâ€ when customers wanted to customize their meals by adding or taking off ingredients. [8] X Research source Handwritten orders might say something like: [9] X Research source â€œ1 burger w/o cheeseâ€ â€œCobb salad w/ extra dressingâ€
